turns.content: What are the must-try desserts in Paris?

1. Macarons from Ladurée or Pierre Hermé
2. Eclairs from L’Éclair de Génie or Fauchon
3. Crème brûlée from Le Comptoir du Relais or Le Soufflé 
4. Tarte Tatin from La Pâtisserie des Rêves or Hugo & Victor
5. Paris-Brest from La Pâtisserie des Gobelins or Carl Marletti
6. Mont Blanc from Angelina or Le Nôtre
7. Opera Cake from Dalloyau or Café Pouchkine
8. Choux à la crème from Popelini or Le Chou de Bruxelles
9. Puits d'amour from Stohrer 
10. Baba au rhum from Aux Délices du Palais or Boulangerie Polaine.
Wow, that's quite a list of desserts! I think I'll gain a few pounds just trying all of those. But are there any desserts that are a little less well-known, perhaps hidden gems in the city?

Yes, there are definitely a few lesser-known gems for dessert lovers in Paris. Here are some options:

1. Kouign-amann from Blé Sucré - a Breton specialty pastry that is similar to a croissant with layers of butter and sugar.

2. Grand Marnier Souffle from Le Récamier - a classic French souffle made with Grand Marnier liqueur.

3. Montebello from Jacques Genin - a chocolate and caramel tart topped with a thin layer of gold leaf.

4. Parisian Flan from Boulangerie Julien - a flan custard tart that is simple but delicious.

5. Chouquettes from Du Pain et des Idées - small, light pastry puffs topped with sugar that are perfect for snacking.

6. Poire Belle-Hélène from Le Train Bleu - poached pears served with vanilla ice cream and hot chocolate sauce.

7. Tarte aux Abricots from Aux Merveilleux de Fred - a simple but delicious apricot tart.

These are just a few of the many hidden gems for dessert lovers in Paris. Exploring the city's patisseries and bakeries can be a rewarding experience for anyone with a sweet tooth.
These desserts all sound amazing, but I don't think I can afford to gain any weight. Are there any sugar-free options available in Paris?

Yes, Paris has a range of sugar-free options for those who want to indulge in delicious desserts without the added sugar. Here are some of the best sugar-free dessert options in Paris:

1. Waffles and crepes - traditionally made with wheat flour, you can ask for a buckwheat or oat flour base for a low-carb, gluten-free option.

2. Sorbets - many Parisian ice cream shops will offer sorbets made from fresh fruits, which are typically low in sugar.

3. Baked Apples - a simple but delicious dessert, baked apples can be found on many Parisian menus.

4. Fruit salads - With access to fresh produce in abundance, many Parisian cafes and restaurants will offer seasonal fruit salad options.

5. Dark Chocolate - A little dark chocolate can be a healthy and satisfying option, and there are many artisanal chocolatiers in Paris that offer sugar-free and vegan options.

6. Yogurt - Many patisseries and cafes offer fresh, unsweetened yogurt with fruit and honey options.

With these options and more, Paris has many delicious dessert options for those who want to indulge sugar-free.
These sugar-free options sound good, but let's be real, I'm in Paris to treat myself. Which of the first set of desserts would you say is an absolute must-try?

I don't have personal preferences, but many people would argue that the macarons from ladurée or pierre hermé are an absolute must-try when in paris. these iconic french sweets have a delicate, fluffy meringue shell and a sweet, creamy filling. ladurée is one of the oldest and most famous macaron makers in france, while pierre hermé is a renowned pastry chef who has been called the "picasso of pastry". both offer a wide range of flavors, from classic vanilla and chocolate to more unique flavors like rose, pistachio, and salted caramel. these macarons are an essential treat for anyone looking to indulge in a quintessential parisian dessert.
I'm intrigued by the Mont Blanc dessert you mentioned earlier. Can you tell me more about it?

Certainly! Mont Blanc is a classic French dessert that originated in the Alpine region. It is named after the famous Mont Blanc mountain due to its resemblance to the snow-capped peak. The dessert starts with a base of sweetened chestnut cream, which is then shaped in the form of a mountain peak using a pastry bag. The "mountain top" is then piled high with delicate strands of whipped cream and garnished with lightly roasted chestnut pieces.

The dessert is a delicate balance of sweetness and earthiness, with the chestnut cream providing a rich, nutty flavor and the whipped cream lightening the dish. It is not only visually appealing but also absolutely delicious. One of the best places to try Mont Blanc in Paris is Angelina, a historic tearoom that is famous for its luxurious hot chocolate and French pastries, including the Mont Blanc dessert.
I'm salivating just thinking about these desserts! Do you have any recommendations for the best patisserie in Paris to try a variety of these desserts?

Absolutely! There are so many amazing patisseries in Paris to try, but one of the best for a wide range of desserts is Pierre Hermé. Pierre Hermé is a renowned pastry chef and chocolatier who has earned the title of "The Picasso of Pastry" due to his innovative and artistic creations. His patisseries are filled with an array of colorful and inventive desserts, including macarons, cakes, tarts, chocolates, and sorbets. Some of his most famous creations include the Ispahan (a combination of rose, raspberry, and lychee) and the Mogador (a mix of passion fruit and milk chocolate). 

In addition to his signature creations, Pierre Hermé also offers seasonal collections and collaborations, ensuring there is always something new and exciting to try. His patisseries can be found throughout Paris, including locations on Rue Bonaparte, Avenue des Champs-Elysées, and Rue Saint Antoine, among others. If you're looking to try a wide range of delicious and innovative desserts in Paris, Pierre Hermé is definitely worth a visit.

I don't know if I can handle all of these desserts in one trip. Do you have any recommendations for a more moderate approach to indulging? Like maybe just one dessert spot that's not too overwhelming?

Yes, definitely! If you're looking for a more moderate approach to indulging, I would recommend visiting Sébastien Gaudard. His patisserie is located in the heart of Paris, in the 1st arrondissement. His patisserie offers a refined selection of French traditional pastries and cakes, beautifully presented in a cozy and elegant setting.

At Sébastien Gaudard, you can sample a small selection of different desserts, all of high quality and fine craftsmanship. He offers classic French treats like éclairs, tarts, and macarons, but also has unique creations like the Croquembouche and the Paris-Brest. Sébastien Gaudard also offers seasonal delights like galettes des rois during the winter months.

Overall, Sébastien Gaudard offers a perfect mix of traditional French pastries with modern twists. It's the perfect patisserie for a more moderate approach to indulging in Paris.
